data.text: Bicycle Fit: Leg Length Discrepancy?

For those with a leg length discrepancy and you know from a bike fitter that your leg is actually shorter than the other one what have you done to resolve the issue? I don’t really want to add spacers under the cleat because now it will stick out further than the shoe. Thank you￼￼. I also don’t want to have one crank shorter.
Not sure on why you don't want to add spacers? How much discrepancy are you dealing with?
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: I wrote the reason in the post. 1 cm
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: you are 10mm shorter in one leg? Like nearly 1/2 inch? I can’t see anyone using a 10mm thick insole. Seems like the shoe would be a pretty snug fit. Dunno. Never had to think about it.
data.author: Michael Troy

data.text: the correcting part doesn’t need to be the same length as the discrepancy. It is typically shorter from what I’ve read so far
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: hmm, I just reread the original and that info wasn't in there. Maybe a combination of spacer and thicker insole?
data.author: Benjamin Arians

data.text: ah. Gotcha. I remember having a saddle that had built in ‘rock’ to it so it accommodated that type of issue. I gave it to somebody with a partial leg amputation and he really liked it. Helped him out.
data.author: Michael Troy

data.text: I've got a small riser in my left shoe by my toes as well as an orthopedic insoles to support my high arches on both sides. My fitter provided me the riser and told me exactly what insoles to order. It was well worth the money. Trying to figure it out yourself might get you close but likely not perfect, let a professional take care of it.
data.author: Ryan Macko

data.text:
Shimano makes https://bike.shimano.com/en-EU/product/service-upgradeparts/shimano/WP-YL8098030.html I know it's not ideal, but a shorter crank affects the entire pedal stroke and something like a thick insole would create its own problems. Between the cleat and the sole is the best spot, or perhaps someone out there makes custom cycling shoes with different sole thicknesses.
WP-YL8098030
bike.shimano.com
data.author: Braden Graham

data.text: I guess it depends on how much. A few millimeters, I wouldn’t worry about. More than that?
data.author: Mike Lamarca

data.text: 1 cm
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: I would get maybe a thicker insole for the short side. That isn’t a huge amount still.
data.author: Mike Lamarca

data.text: Add an insole. Or move the cleat back/forward. Did your bike fitter not make suggestions?
data.author: Andrew Waung

data.text: yes. He wants to add a shim under the cleat but the shims he had in stock were wimpy plastic and not firm enough when unclipping. The cleat was sticking out beyond the shoe which I don’t want to deal with.
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: Cleat position
data.author: Walter Sitter

data.text: 1 cm shim would be an easy fix.
data.author: Chris Owens

data.text: There are few people in the world that are symmetrical so unless you have a significant difference just ride your bike. Possibly have your saddle height accordingly.
data.author: Bill Dove

data.text: I’ve addressed this for a couple of cyclists, I generally only correct 1/2 of the discrepancy. My most severe case was 30mm. I made a 16mm thick spacer for the cleat. Do you wear corrections in your street shoes? For you I would start with a 5 mm spacer, and see how it feels.
data.author: Marlin Erin

data.text: this reply is 100% correct.
data.author: Doug Hanna

data.text: Unless you're racing in the pro peloton it doesn't matter
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: bike fitter identified it. You can see it on video. I don’t want hip problems when I get older. I’m racing in (8)65-100 mile gravel races in my first season. There is no reason to ignore this.
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: it does matter. Power out put, hip issues like he stated and also you can develop numbness in areas such as hands, arms, etc.
data.author: Michael Watts

data.text: If it is identified while pedaling it could be a multitude of issues, not just leg length discrepancy. How did he actually measure your discrepancy before you go doing things that can ACTUALLY cause you long term problems vs fixing the real issue. IE: if not a true discrepancy and you shim then you will let your body just adapt to a problem. If it is a soft tissue issue then you need to be in PT to correct that.
data.author: Mike Kavan

data.text: L tibia measured to be 1cm shorter. He’s a legit bike fitter and PT. It’s structural. I do wear custom orthotics to deal with my feet pronating but just have the standard bike shoe insole so far.
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: I have the same issue. Split the deference in your saddle hight and a small shim and you'll be fine.
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: like I said unless you're racing pro... I have the same issue it's not a big deal for me. There's many other adjustments you can do for numbness
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: Been ignoring it since I broke my tibia in 78.
data.author: Peter Moorman

data.text: your choice. I’m looking for input that doesn’t involve “ignore it”
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: It has not been an issue in 50 years on the bike. If it causes you pain definitely get to an orthopedic specialist. It actually normal to have foot,eye,hand,limb of different sizes. If your walking around like that your body had already adapted.
data.author: Peter Moorman

data.text: I have never seen a leg length comparison done to truly determine a real discrepancy outside imaging and measuring and as mentioned below many have them. I currently have a noticeable leg length issue (not usually noticeable) but it is because of a very tight muscle. Adding a shim would not be a good idea in my situation because I need to work out the real problem, not put a crutch on it.
data.author: Mike Kavan

data.text: Corrective insoles for the win.
data.author: Jim Evans

data.text: I’m in that position due to bad hip alignment. I can either do multiple sessions at a chiropractor or set my seatpost between knee pain and back pain for no pain.
data.author: Chuck Schneickert

data.text: I'd take up yoga and strength training to start, preferably with someone specializing in sports/cycling specifics, minimize any discrepancies.
data.author: Brent Lester

data.text: Not a thing been riding forever not an issue
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: maybe not for you. It is a thing causing issues for me. Everyone’s body is different.
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: As a physical therapist with over 30 years of experience please know you can only be sure of a leg length difference by x-ray. Using a tape measure is completely unreliable. Visual inspection with knees straight also completely unreliable. Without an x-ray it’s a guess…
data.author: Doug Hanna

data.text: What is your fitter’s solution?
data.author: Mike Vandale

data.text: to add spacers between cleat and shoe. It sticks out beyond the traction of the shoe a fair amount. Walking will be clunky. Really don’t want to deal with that
data.author: Chad Underwood

data.text: ideally you’re riding the bike more than walking it. The only reason to walk is usually mud or a mechanical. Mud doesn’t last for a whole race and if a mechanical is bad enough, your race is over. Just my opinion, but I’d what to be as efficient and comfortable as possible while riding. I’d go with the fitter’s solution no matter what it looks like.
data.author: Mike Vandale

data.text: crankarm length difference is not the solution. you need to get one pedal higher than the other (different models, or if an adjustable one exists). or a spacer.
data.author: Timm Sima

data.text: I went to a fitter - PT & cyclist. We tried a number of things. Best result? Longer leg cleat is more @ midfoot, shorter leg cleat about 3/4” forward of that. Worked wonders.
data.author: Andy Towlen
